image.altText: a woman with a black top holding a phone

props.synopsis: Hundreds of coin collectors forwent the late night revelry of New Year's Eve in favour of an early morning visit to the Royal Australian Mint in Canberra, hoping to get their hands on the highly-sought-after first coin of the year.

title.children: Australia mints world's first coins for the year after ballot

image.altText: NSW Police LIDAR speed gun

props.synopsis: As double demerit periods come to an end for the holiday season, participating states and territories say they make roads safer. But there has been no peer-reviewed Australian research on the topic for years.

title.children: Governments say data strongly supports double demerits for road safety

image.altText: A large concrete structure with ventilation and a mural of Australian animals.

props.synopsis: Sewage is known to produce a 'rotten egg' like smell, which utilities companies employ a range of measures to stop from being released onto the streets.

title.children: If left alone, sewer pipes could stink out cities with 'rotten egg' smells

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios smiles and looks behind him

props.synopsis: Nick Kyrgios said he would need "a miracle" for his wrist to hold up during a grand slam, so moments like those at the Brisbane International need to be cherished.

title.children: Fun while it lasted, Nick and Novak's time in the sun ends

image.altText: a close-up of a person holding a glass under a running tap, filling it with water

props.synopsis: Expecting to need another water source by the end of next decade, Canberra's water authority is considering whether the city will need to supplement the drinking water supply with purified treated sewage water in the future.

title.children: ACT authorities consider supplementing drinking water with treated sewage water

image.altText: A street sign with four street names on it pointing in four different directions.

props.synopsis: While many of Canberra's suburbs and streets are unsurprisingly named after prime ministers and pioneers, there are some quirky exceptions and places that have taken on double meanings.

title.children: New Canberra suburb street names to strike more of a gender balance

image.altText: A young man sitting on the sand at a beach wearing a parka

props.synopsis: NSW Police say search efforts for Hadi Nazari, who has been missing for six days in the Kosciuszko National Park, involves specialist bushwalkers in steep vegetated terrain.

title.children: Search continues for missing bushwalker in 'most rugged terrain' in NSW

image.altText: a river with a warning sign

props.synopsis: The man was swimming in the Murrumbidgee River at Pine Island with family and friends when he experienced trouble in the water and failed to resurface on Sunday afternoon.

title.children: 21-year-old man drowns at popular Canberra river swimming spot

image.altText: The four women stand in a group hugging each other and smiling.

props.synopsis: Adventure racing is a competitive endurance sport featuring non-stop multi-day trekking, using a map and compass to navigate via mountain bike, kayak and on foot. This all-woman team was the first to win a major international race. So why couldn't they claim the prize?

title.children: This all-women adventure racing team made history by beating men half their age

image.altText: Powerlines suspended between towers against orange dusk sky.

props.synopsis: Reporting profits and losses is standard fare in corporate Australia, but from this week companies will be required to disclose the risks and opportunities they will face under a warming climate.

title.children: New climate laws creating 'degree of nervousness' among company execs

image.altText: A policewoman with light brown-blonde hair smiling while wearing a light blue top and dark blue 'police' branded vest

props.synopsis: New Zealand Police Senior Sergeant Lyn Fleming, who has been remembered as a 'widely respected officer with 38 years frontline service',  has died in hospital from her injuries.

title.children: Driver runs down two New Zealand police officers, killing one

image.altText: An older woman with blonde hair and prominent facial features wears a rich-looking gown at night.

props.synopsis: The cosmetic surgery aficionado became a New York socialite after marrying art dealer Alec Wildenstein.

title.children: Swiss socialite Jocelyne Wildenstein dies

image.altText: Full car park in Hobart

props.synopsis: We've all been there — approaching the car after a long day and noticing a slip of paper under the windscreen wiper. But what if you aren't parked on a public street?

title.children: Do you have to pay a fine issued by the owner of a private car park?

image.altText: An older man looks out a car window from inside with his arm resting on the car, he has big teeth showing and is wearing a hat

props.synopsis: Chad Morgan is one of Australian country music's most recognisable pioneers, with his upturned hat, signature smile and country comedy hits. Fans are remembering his long career following his death on New Year's Day.

title.children: Australian country music icon Chad Morgan dies after 70-year career

image.altText: Jordan Thompson pumps his right first after a point

props.synopsis: Jordan Thompson is often at his best when his back is against the wall, and it proved to be the case once again in his match against an American young gun.

title.children: Stirring comeback helps Thompson advance to Brisbane International quarters

image.altText: A toy kangaroo rests on an Australia flag themed pencil case on a beach

props.synopsis: Woolworths says it will “do more” to celebrate Australia Day this year by running in-store promotions focusing on food and produce after calls to boycott the store last year.

title.children: Woolworths says it will 'do more' to celebrate Australia Day

image.altText: A hand using a mobile phone credit card to pay.

props.synopsis: A technology update may cause some debit cards saved to digital wallets to stop functioning in the new year. But there is a simple fix.

title.children: Why your digital EFTPOS card may have stopped working from January 1

image.altText: A Ukrainian solider shakes hands with a robotic dog on the battlefield.

props.synopsis: Throughout the year, global conflicts illustrated the growing impact of drones in warfare, with jam-proof fibre optics, AI capabilities, and robot dogs among the new developments in 2024.

title.children: Drone warfare boomed in 2024. Now 2025 promises to deliver its own surprises

image.altText: Grey plastic boxes filled with and surrounded by yellow and blue-capped explosive devices lined up on a table

props.synopsis: FBI alleges more than 150 homemade bombs, a jar of highly-explosive material and a notebook filled with 'recipes' for making explosives were found in a raid on a farm in Virginia.

title.children: FBI says it has made 'largest seizure of explosives' in its history

image.altText: A money tin laying on its side featuring a print of a green Australian one hundred dollar note

props.synopsis: The Australian dollar has fallen sharply, hitting a multi-year low not seen since October, 2022.

title.children: Australian dollar inching toward levels where RBA may step in

image.altText: For Rent sign outside a property.

props.synopsis: A property investor sell-off is speeding up in Victoria, with the state's rental stock falling at an increasingly rapid pace.

title.children: Victorian rentals fall by nearly 25,000 as investor sell-off heats up

image.altText: A bus on George Street at Thebarton.

props.synopsis: Police say a fight between two groups on an Adelaide public bus led to three people including a woman with head injuries being taken to hospital, as well as 19 arrests.

title.children: Police arrest 19, including 13yo, after woman injured in SA bus fight

image.altText: A man and a woman smile at each other during karaoke, against a neon backdrop.

props.synopsis: Three lawsuits have now been filed in relation to the alleged smear campaign against and sexual harassment of Blake Lively by It Ends with Us co-star Justin Baldoni.

title.children: Blake Lively files lawsuit, Justin Baldoni sues New York Times for $400 million

image.altText: White church stands amongst the palm trees.

props.synopsis: When Saibai Islanders were looking for a place to build their first church 150 years ago, they chose the highest point they could see. Now, it's sitting on the foreshore.

title.children: This church has stood for 150 years — but it's never been more important

image.altText: An empty street with the rubble of a destroyed shop piled up on the side, and a tilted pole on the opposite side of the road.

props.synopsis: It's unclear when Port Vila's CBD, usually buzzing with holiday activity, will reopen to the public more than two weeks after a deadly magnitude-7.3 earthquake struck.

title.children: Vanuatu capital's entire CBD remains off-limits following disaster

image.altText: A large shark has dried blood and dull scales, it sits on dry grass, dumped on a farm

props.synopsis: Vicki Matchett is all too familiar with rubbish being dumped outside her rural property south of Adelaide — but when she was passing her farm gate several days ago, she saw what "looked like a shark's fin poking up".

title.children: Shark found dumped outside farm believed to be bronze whaler

image.altText: Jackie has shoulder length brown hair and wears a grey top with a white Nike brand and stands beside a window.

props.synopsis: In 2022, only 12 students living in residential care were enrolled in year 12 and none of them completed VCE. The Children's Commissioner says the Victorian government has failed to help.

title.children: 'They're being failed': Alarming education outcomes for children in care

image.altText: Noah Balta, wearing a black gurnsey with yellow sash, celebrates next to the goal post

props.synopsis: Richmond Tiger Noah Balta has been charged with assault by NSW Police following an alleged altercation on Monday, the club has said.

title.children: Richmond Tiger Noah Balta charged with assault

image.altText: John Howard head and shoulders shot speaking while standing in front of an Australian flag. He wears a suit and tie

props.synopsis: Hundreds of previously secret cabinet records have been made public in the National Archives' annual release.

title.children: We pored over the newly unsealed 2004 cabinet files. Here's what stood out

image.altText: A composite image of Donald Trump holding his fist up, moo deng the pygmy hippo and Taylor Swift blowing a kiss.

props.synopsis: Can you answer all our questions about last year's biggest stories and key moments correctly? See how close you get to a perfect score.

title.children: Moo Deng, the Eras Tour and more — how much do you remember about 2024?

image.altText: Man with a grey beard leaning next to a saw sharpening bench in a workshop.

props.synopsis: The WA government insists its native timber logging ban was well planned and timber towns are now thriving, but others say they are falling through the cracks.

title.children: Big divide remains in timber towns, a year after native logging ban

image.altText: Empty iron ore wagons on train tracks in bushland near Kalgoorlie.

props.synopsis: WA's Yilgarn region has been home to iron ore mining on and off since the 1950s, but the final trainload of the steel-making ingredient has arrived at Esperance Port.

title.children: End of an era as last train from WA iron ore mine arrives at port

image.altText: An underwater photo of a spear fun and shark swimming around a reef.

props.synopsis: A recent fatal shark attack in Queensland prompts warnings for people to be on the lookout for deadly marine creatures these holidays.

title.children: Fatal shark attack prompts warnings about deadly creatures

image.altText: A child leaning on a rail looking at a river

props.synopsis: The Harding River, known as the Ngurin to the land's traditional owners, flows for the first time in years in Western Australia's Pilbara region, after rain rings in the new year.

title.children: 'Juicy' Pilbara storms wash away 2024 and replenish long-dry river

image.altText: a baker with a wooden paddle near a traditional wood-fire oven

props.synopsis: Scotch ovens used to be the golden-brown standard in Australia, until commercial bakeries and supermarkets extinguished the flames to shut down the competition. But for the last 100 years, no offer has stopped this team of traditional, long-ferment bakers from firing up.

title.children: Century-old Scotch wood-fired oven keeps traditional slow ferment dough dream alive
